title: Corrections & Amplifications
text:
The chip maker Xilinx Inc. is based in San Jose, Calif. A Business & Finance article on Tuesday about a new product from Nvidia Corp. incorrectly said Xilinx is based in San Diego.

(See: "Nvidia Plans New Chip to Compete With Intel" -- WSJ April 13, 2021)

---

Sultan Mahmud II led the Ottoman Empire during the Greek War of Independence. His name was incorrectly given as Mehmet in a Review essay on Saturday about the war.

(See: "REVIEW --- How Poetry Won Independence For Greece --- Two hundred years ago, the Greek revolution against Ottoman rule became a European cause thanks to the support of writers and artists." -- WSJ April 10, 2021)

---

The slotted fish spatula from New West KnifeWorks is made in Victor, Idaho. A headline with an Off Duty article on Saturday about the product incorrectly said it is made in the Midwest.

(See: "OFF DUTY --- Eating & Drinking -- Power Tool: A Good Turn --- Designed for flipping fragile fish, this Midwest-made kitchen tool brings finesse to all sorts of fiddly cooking tasks" -- WSJ April 10, 2021)

---

The last name of Shaun Davies, a professor at University of Colorado, was given incorrectly as Davis in a Journal Report article on Monday about target-date funds.

(See: "Encore (A Special Report) --- Target-Date Funds, After Retirement: Should you move your money into an individual retirement account?" -- WSJ April 12, 2021)

---

Notice to readers

Wall Street Journal staff members are working remotely during the pandemic. For the foreseeable future, please send reader comments only by email or phone, using the contacts below, not via U.S. Mail.

---

Readers can alert The Wall Street Journal to any errors in news articles by e-mailing wsjcontact@wsj.com or by calling 888-410-2667.
